p: The purported underlying mechanism behind these phenomena might involve both nonspecific immunity and influenzavirus-specific immunity ( 19). After a viral infection, temporary nonspecific immunity against a second infection is induced, which could last for several weeks ( 20). Given its brief duration, investigators might be unlikely to observe a population or cohort effect. In contrast, the influenzavirus-specific interference may involve T-cell-mediated immunity, which may last for months because of broad heterotypic cross-reactivity. The immune response might vary across different influenza strains and could possibly be more evident during an influenza pandemic wherein specific influenza strains predominate during the season ( 19). Although the nonspecific and specific immunity against influenza and other infectious diseases has been broadly described, the potential nature and biological mechanisms of virus interference remain unclear ( 21).
